summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16269 E; Qurʾānic Text: Q 59:11-59:17; 4 lines per page; Dimensions: 180 x 123mm.

The provenance of this manuscript cannot be determined with certainty, but the script gives some indication as to its origins. The horizontal format was abandoned in the Islamic West in the second half of the 11th century, but the ‘modern’ symbols for fatḥa, ḍamma, and kasra were only introduced in Maghribī Qurʾāns in the first half of the same century. Hence, the manuscript can be safely dated to the 11th century. The script is akin to Ifrīqī bookhands from Kairouan as attested in the 10th and 11th centuries, including the distinctive way of dotting fāʾ with one dot below the letter and qāf with one dot above it. A further indicator of a Maghribī origin is the use of a semicircle for the tašdīd. Sparse folios from similar manuscripts are today kept in the National Laboratory for the Preservation and Conservation of Parchment and Manuscripts (NLPCPM) in Raqqada, from the library of the Great Mosque of Kairouan.
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museum in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 166):

"142. Inv. E. 16269. 5th-6th century A. H./11th-12th century A. D. Tan, rather thick parchment. 12.3 x 18 cm. Full size sheet written on both faces, seven lines to the page, in light brown ink. All margins are well preserved as also the inner margin of an opposite sheet in the quire. Upper margin: 1.5 cm., lower: 2.6 cm., outer: 2.8 cm., inner: 2 cm. Several holes and stains have partially obliterated the writing. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 59,11 وان – 14 جميعا (second). Verso: 59,14 وقلوبهم – 17 انهما. Heavy, ackward [sic!] Maghrabī script. Diacritical signs, vowel marks and orthographic signs are in the same ink as the consonants. No verse dividers."
